title: 115_s866
content: The Act may be cited as the "Prohibiting Detention of Youth Status Offenders Act of 2017" and focuses on the deinstitutionalization of status offenders. Section 223 of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating orders. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders. The court must issue a written order identifying the violated court order, providing the factual basis for the violation, and stating that there is no less restrictive alternative available. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to address the placement of juveniles in secure detention or correctional facilities for violating court orders. The court must issue a written order specifying the length of time, not to exceed 3 days, that the juvenile may remain in a secure facility, including a release plan, and prohibiting renewal or extension of the stay. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to limit the time a juvenile can be held in a secure detention or correctional facility to 3 days, with exceptions for weekends and holidays. Procedures are in place to prevent juveniles from remaining in these facilities longer than authorized by the court or state law. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to limit the time a juvenile can be held in a secure detention or correctional facility to 3 days, with exceptions for weekends and holidays. A juvenile status offender may only be held in such a facility 1 time in any 6-month period, with additional requirements for states receiving formula grants under this part. Juveniles facing hardship can apply for a 1-year extension to comply with reducing the number of status offenders in detention facilities. The application must show progress, effort, and a plan for compliance within the extension period.
